entry.title: abduction of the Sabine women twice (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Poussin painted the abduction of the Sabine women twice (one pictured), once for a prince and once for a cardinal?

entry.title: the leader (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the leader of the German Red Cross under the Nazi regime had lived in the UK until he was fifteen years old and was a grandson of Queen Victoria?

entry.title: a change in government policy (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that New Zealand petrol stations were filled with queues before a change in government policy?

entry.title: Grigor Yeghiazaryan (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that although five of Armenian composer Grigor Yeghiazaryan's siblings died of starvation from the Armenian genocide, his life was saved because he played in a brass band?

entry.title: Edo literature (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Edo literature was influenced by British colonialism in the late 19th century, which introduced the Roman script and Christianity to the Edo people?

entry.title: a New York state TV station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that a New York state TV station thought a St. Bernard could serve as a mascot—until she proved incapable of following direction and had to be sent to obedience school?

entry.title: Harald Hasselbach (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Harald Hasselbach, the only Dutch Super Bowl champion, lived in four continents in his youth?

entry.title: ended with a sneeze (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that life always ended with a sneeze until the time of Jacob, according to one Midrash?
